Azerbaijan's experience shows that when our future, our destiny is in our hands, we can do more in comparison with previous times
Our experience can be a good example of how to change the country and provide a better life for the citizens.
Today, our statehood has solid foundations. We have carried out extensive political and economic reforms that modernize our country.
A happy spring May holiday to all! http://t.co/ubm6EJWY0L
We have developed democracy, fundamental freedoms, including an integral part of our present life (cont) http://t.co/Gq6S2J9RLw
Without a sound economic foundation, our independence can not be complete.
Therefore, economic reforms in Azerbaijan are being implemented in parallel with political reforms.
The level of Azerbaijan's foreign debt is very small, with only 8% of the gross domestic product.
This means we can plan more actively with international financial institutions.
Diversification of the economy, investments in social infrastructure provide such a lifestyle in remote areas.
Construction of three thousand secondary schools, five hundred hospitals and other factors gave our society an entirely new environment.
Economic development is supported by very serious social programs. Social issues for our government have always been a priority.
Improving living standards, opening jobs, and reducing unemployment, all of which can be done.
There are four UN Security Council resolutions demanding immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Armenian troops from our territories.
None of these resolutions were implemented. The occupation continues. We were exposed to ethnic cleansing.
The historic part of our country, Nagorno-Karabakh and its seven surrounding districts have been occupied for more than 20 years.
It supports our international law, justice and history.
But we clearly understand that it is not enough to restore justice and international law. To do this, we must be stronger
Regrettably, we see that power is at the forefront of international relations agenda.
The key priority for us is the restoration of our territorial integrity, strengthening our independence, and more (cont) http://t.co/c1tKGisbi

@kasujja your question 1: As Jo said there are no district hospitals. There are general, regional & national hospitals.
@kasujja the general hospitals are not "fully functional" as you defined them. Very many of them are reasonably functional.
Today, during my visit to Zonguldak, I came to work in coal miners working in quarries. http://t.co/ti4pexlor9
@kasujja the World Bank loan of $90m. is for the purpose of rehabilitating 17 such hospitals.
I had a conversation with our workers who were hiding hundreds of meters underground. http://t.co/vpjsykorxm
@kasujja Also borrowed from Spain and Islamic Development Fund for Kawolo, Yumbe and Kayunga hospitals. Plus 27 Health Centre 4s.
@kasujja one of these, Naguru Hospital built by the Chinese Gvt. has been completed. The others will be Kirudu in Makindye & Kawempe Hspt.
@kasujja these will be a big addition 2 the existing functional hospitals. 3 new hosptls 2 be built in Kampala 2 decongest Mulago Hospital
@kasujja So Gvt has a vigorous prog to uplift the functionality & standards of the existing hospitals and build new ones.
@kasujja regional referral hospitals like Kabale, Jinja, Gulu, Mbarara, etc have been significantly improved. More work is under way.
@kasujja for eg Japanese funds are earmarked for that work. 13 hospitals have been done & work on an extra 4 is underway.
@kasujja your question2. Yes Gvt has an acceptable healthcare programme given the challenges we face today. A lot still needs to be done.
@kasujja we're in the process of introducing healthcare insurance scheme. Cabinet already approved the principles of a law for that purpose
@kasujja the Bill is being drafted & should be before Parliament in the near future.
@kasujja Gvt policy is essentially to prevent disease & promote good health. So we concentrate for eg on things like immunisation and
@kasujja providing safe drinking water. These & other measures prevent infectious & noncommunicable diseases. Gvt will supply 21million nets
@kasujja these will prevent malaria infection. Incidentally on immunisation Uganda is only second to South Africa in the whole continent.

(2)  first, the politics needed; second, the policies needed, and third, the polity needed to achieve the first two. In that order.
